results.title: Art in Australia
results.brief_description: Melbourne is an art conscious city, the centre of which is the National Gallery, housing many old masters and other works of art. The film shows the contribution to this interest in art being made by the annual Dunlop Art Contest. The film shows some of the work involved in the unpacking, cataloguing and judging of the hundreds of entries from all over Australia, and concludes with views of the 1951 winning entries with comments on each by the judges. No other credits available.

results.title: Art from found materials
results.brief_description: Many artists use ‘found materials’ with imagination. They use such natural things as seeds and shells as well as scrap materials. Both collage and assemblage are illustrated. The materials used, their organisation, and techniques for adhering offer endless possibilities for creative form and images. No other credits available.

results.title: The Art director
results.creator_credit: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Explains the work of the art director in the production of a feature motion picture. Shows how motion picture sets are designed and constructed and indicate the research necessary to make them authentic. Suitable for Mid-Secondary and above students. No other credits available.

results.title: Art and the community
results.brief_description: This film is a Commonwealth Teleview. Sir William Emrys Williams, Secretary-General of the Arts Council of Great Britain, answers questions put to him by Rooney Pelletier on various aspects of art sponsorship, with particular reference to the encouragement of opera, the theatre, music, ballet, painting and sculpture in Britain. No other credits available.

results.title: Art and reality: the Renaissance
results.creator_credit: John Warner, John Seabourne, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Seabourne Enterprises
results.brief_description: This film illustrates the fundamental change form Byzantine symbolism to Renaissance humanism. A simple but comprehensive study is made of composition and perspective, the visual aspects of painting and on attitudes inspired by early Renaissance humanism. Suitable for Lower-Upper Secondary students.

results.title: Art and perception: learning to see
results.brief_description: The viewer is encouraged to look for the visual elements of art- colour, line, texture and form- as the film explores different settings: the country, the city and the seashore. Presents a variety of paintings of these environments that illustrate the visual inspiration and imaginative inventiveness the artist brought to his subject. No other credits available.

results.title: Art and life in Italy
results.brief_description: Italy: the countryside, architecture and sculpture. Rome: the Colosseum, Pantheon, and St Peter’s Cathedral, church interiors, mosaics; a Giotto fresco. Florence: Cathedral dome and bronze doors, Medici palaces, Raphael’s painting. Botticelli’s “Adoration of the Magi”: Della Robbia’s “Singing Angels” and Michelangelo’s “Figure of Moses”. Venice : the churches. No other credits available.

results.title: Art and life in Belgium (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Charles Dekeukeleire, Henri Kerels and PDK Pictures
results.brief_description: The countryside of Flanders, Brabant and Wallonia in Belgium has for centuries attracted artists who have interpreted the changing seasons and depicted various types of inhabitants of the regions. This film shows how these sources of inspiration have remained unchanged. Comparisons of the work of artists of different periods with the landscape and types of inhabitants to be seen in Flanders and the surrounding districts today. Artists whose work is illustrated include P. Breughel, Rubens and Van Eyck.

results.title: Art
results.brief_description: Presents a short and frantic history of painting and graphics, combined with Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony. Uses an animated still-picture technique, sometimes called “kinestasis”.

results.title: Arrow to the sun
results.brief_description: A film which uses animation to tell the tale of the Acoma Pueblo Indians about a boy’s search for his father, entailing his voyage on an arrow to the Sun, trials he undergoes in the sky village until he is recognised by his father, the lord of the sun, and his return to earth to spread the sun’s warm delights. Based on the Caldecott Medal winning book by Gerald McDermott.
